page.title: 03WILDLIFE IN WILLINGDON
page.content: The South Downs are close to their eastern end here. The typical wildlife of chalk grass land is abundant. One may enjoy basilthyme, cowslips, stemless thistle,clumps of gorse and hillsides of orchids. Butterflies include fritillaries, the chalk-hill blue and the brimstone. There are adders, grass snakes and slow worms.One can see swallows, flocks of gold finches, skylarks, magpies, kestrels and sparrowhawks. Owls can be heard at night. Rabbits seem to be recovering in numbers. There are hares, moles,foxes and badgers. When myxomatosis was introduced in 1954 the number of rabbits declined and the grassland became overgrown. Sheep have been introduced at Chalk Farm to reverse this trend.
